verbatim.problem_statement: The presence of children in a family often destroys the closeness and the special privacy which a man and wife need together.
verbatim.solution_statement: Make a special part of the house distinct from the common areas and all the children's rooms, where the man and woman of the house can be together in private. Give this place a quick path to the children's rooms, but, at all costs, make it a distinctly separate realm.

forces.name: couple privacy vs. parental accessibility
forces.pole_a: the couple needs a protected, intimate world insulated from children's presence and awareness
forces.pole_b: parents need to remain close enough to respond quickly to children, especially infants, in emergencies
forces.description: Core tension: the couple must be both psychologically separate from and physically proximate to their children's realm
forces.resolved_by: a distinct couple's realm with a quick path to children's rooms but psychological and acoustic separation

forces.name: acoustic privacy vs. open household
forces.pole_a: thin shared walls and open circulation allow children to hear and interrupt the couple's private life
forces.pole_b: a fully sealed, remote realm would isolate the couple from household life and emergency awareness
forces.description: Physical design of standard houses permits sound and movement to penetrate the couple's space, destroying intimacy
forces.resolved_by: double doors or ante-room buffer, and acoustically thicker separation between couple's realm and children's rooms

forces.name: couple identity vs. parental role
forces.pole_a: the adult relationship between partners requires its own space, time, and shared private life
forces.pole_b: parenthood and child-rearing dominate household attention and physical space when no separate realm exists
forces.description: Without a dedicated realm, the couple's identity as partners is subsumed entirely by their role as parents
forces.resolved_by: a self-contained domain — sitting area, bed, dressing, bathing — that constitutes a complete world for the couple

forces.name: territorial completeness vs. spatial economy
forces.pole_a: the couple's realm must be a complete domain with sitting, sleeping, dressing, and bathing to function as a true world
forces.pole_b: space in a family home is finite and pressure exists to reduce the couple's area to merely a bedroom
forces.description: A bedroom alone is insufficient; completeness of the realm matters even if each element is small
forces.resolved_by: embedding a sitting area, alcoved bed, dressing room, and ideally bathing room within the couple's realm even at small scale

typed_rules.metric: Couple's realm separation from children's rooms
typed_rules.preferred_value: psychologically far and acoustically buffered from children's rooms
typed_rules.rationale: The realm must be distinctly separate — 'at all costs' — to protect the couple's private life from constant parental awareness
typed_rules.source_text: at all costs, make it a distinctly separate realm

typed_rules.rationale: Parents must be able to reach children rapidly in emergencies, particularly with infants
typed_rules.source_text: Give this place a quick path to the children's rooms

typed_rules.preferred_value: double door or ante-room at entry to couple's realm
typed_rules.rationale: An acoustic and visual buffer at the threshold is needed to protect the realm's privacy from the rest of the house
typed_rules.source_text: it needs some kind of a double door, an ante-room, to protect its privacy

typed_rules.preferred_value: bed tucked into alcove with its own window, not open in main sitting area
typed_rules.rationale: The bed should be part of the realm but set apart to allow the sitting area to function independently for conversation and projects
typed_rules.source_text: the bed is part of it, but tucked away into an alcove with its own window

typed_rules.preferred_value: private entrance to outdoors or balcony
typed_rules.rationale: Direct outdoor access reinforces the realm's independence and completeness as a private world
typed_rules.source_text: perhaps with its own entrance to the outdoors, to a balcony

typed_rules.preferred_value: walls must provide sufficient acoustic privacy; standard thin walls are insufficient
typed_rules.rationale: Thin walls allow children's proximity to permeate the couple's private life and destroy intimacy
typed_rules.source_text: The walls of the master bedroom are usually too thin to afford much acoustical privacy

adjacency_rules.note: Couple's realm completes and supports the family structure pattern
Couple's realm helps complete the house for a small family
Couple's realm is a version of House for a Couple embedded in the larger family house
Couple's realm ties to a particular position on the intimacy gradient and can help generate it
Marriage bed within the realm should have morning light from the east
Bathing room ideally opens off the couple's realm to keep it self-contained

adjacency_rules.target_pattern_name: Light on Two Sides of Every Room
adjacency_rules.note: Couple's realm should receive light on two sides
Even a tiny couple's realm must have a sitting area for relaxation, reading, music, and private conversation
Bed is placed at the heart of the couple's realm, tucked into an alcove
Dressing room placed beside the marriage bed within the couple's realm
Governs the fine-detail shape and construction of the couple's realm spaces
Two doors or closets used to keep the area private
Low doorway used as a privacy threshold into the couple's realm

failure_modes.description: When children can circulate freely through the entire house, they dominate all spaces and no room remains private for the couple.
failure_modes.violated_rule: Couple's realm separation from children's rooms
failure_modes.symptom: The couple's private life is continually interrupted; their role as parents permeates all aspects of their intimate relations.
failure_modes.source_text: Children are able to run everywhere in the house, and therefore tend to dominate all of it. No rooms are private.

failure_modes.description: When the bathroom is placed so adults must pass children's bedrooms to reach it, children's proximity infiltrates even nocturnal adult movements.
failure_modes.symptom: Adults cannot move privately within the house at night; every bathroom trip is a reminder of the children's presence.
failure_modes.source_text: The bathroom is often placed so that adults must walk past children's bedrooms to reach it.

failure_modes.description: When bedroom walls are acoustically thin, the couple is constantly aware of children nearby and cannot achieve intimacy.
failure_modes.symptom: Private life is permeated by parental awareness; the couple cannot speak, make love, or share sorrow without acoustic exposure to children.
failure_modes.source_text: The walls of the master bedroom are usually too thin to afford much acoustical privacy.

failure_modes.description: When the couple's realm is reduced to only a bedroom without sitting area, dressing space, or bathing access, it fails to function as a complete private world.
failure_modes.symptom: The realm cannot sustain private life beyond sleep; conversation, projects, and relaxation have no protected place, so the couple reverts to shared family spaces.
failure_modes.source_text: It is a place not only insulated from the children's world, but also complete in itself, a world, a domain.

failure_modes.description: When no privacy buffer exists at the entrance to the couple's realm, children and household noise breach the threshold freely.
failure_modes.symptom: The realm offers no psychological transition from household to private life; intimacy is disrupted by sudden entry and ambient sound.
failure_modes.source_text: it needs some kind of a double door, an ante-room, to protect its privacy
